body:
Hi,
to try the SincNet model on your own dataset you should provide in input our own input files (in wav format) and your own labels. To do it, you should modify the paths into the *.scp files you find in the data_lists folder. To assign to each sentence the right label, you also have modify the dictionary "TIMIT_labels.npy".  You should then modify the config file (cfg/SincNet_TIMIT.cfg) according to your new paths. Remember also to modify the field "class_lay=462" according to the number of speakers in your dataset.

Thanks for your inputs. We have a small training set to start with. Hoping
to improve on them in days to come. Will follow your steps and try
training.

How do I label? From the TIMIT base I see the filename being different for
each training sample. Is the filename being used to label?

Thanks,
Sivam.

On Tue, Sep 18, 2018 at 7:47 PM Mirco Ravanelli <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Hi,
> to try the SincNet model on your own dataset you should provide in input
> our own input files (in wav format) and your own labels. To do it, you
> should modify the paths into the *.scp files you find in the data_lists
> folder. To assign to each sentence the right label, you also have modify
> the dictionary "TIMIT_labels.npy". You should then modify the config file
> (cfg/SincNet_TIMIT.cfg) according to your new paths. Remember also to
> modify the field "class_lay=462" according to the number of speakers in
> your dataset.
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/mravanelli/SincNet/issues/3#issuecomment-422410770>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AmZiiK660SSl8-q3x4jml00d4z-TgT89ks5ucQB9gaJpZM4WtMcl>
> .
>

The label should be a python dictionary that contains a sentence ids as key (e.g., "si1027") and a speaker_ids as values. Each speaker_id is an integer,  ranging from 0  to N_speakers-1.  In the TIMIT dataset, you can easily retrieve the speaker id from the path (e.g., train/dr1/fcjf0/si1027.wav is the sentence_id "si1027" uttered by the speaker "fcjf0"). For other datasets, you should be able to retrieve in such a way this dictionary containing pairs of speaker and sentence ids.

Okay. But for our experiment, we have all the speakers (training set)
speaking the *same sentence or phrase *(We call this a wakeup phrase, quite
like Alexa used by Amazon). Our idea is to decipher who spoke from perhaps
the voice characteristics. Will that not work with this net?

Regards,
Sivam.

On Wed, Sep 19, 2018 at 6:54 PM Mirco Ravanelli <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> The label should be a python dictionary that contains a sentence ids as
> key (e.g., "si1027") and a speaker_ids as values. Each speaker_id is an
> integer, ranging from 0 to N_speakers-1. In the TIMIT dataset, you can
> easily retrieve the speaker id from the path (e.g.,
> train/dr1/fcjf0/si1027.wav is the sentence_id "si1027" uttered by the
> speaker "fcjf0"). For other datasets, you should be able to retrieve in
> such a way this dictionary containing pairs of speaker and sentence ids.
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/mravanelli/SincNet/issues/3#issuecomment-422801741>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AmZiiKgel92n4PQH9gNptk-2pt-SNDbfks5uckVvgaJpZM4WtMcl>
> .
>
Sure! The content of the sentence itself is not important. What is important is give the network the right set of labels and inputs....

Our requirement is as below:
We will have one person whom we will refer to as key person. We have
collected training set from different people including from key person all
uttering Alexa. Our intent is to train the network with the training set.
Then during inference, when the key person says "Alexa", we would want the
net to say... identified keyperson and for rest of the people's input, say
none.

How do I go about using the code for this? Appreciating your time and
explanations.

Thanks,
Sivam.


On Thu, Sep 20, 2018 at 8:29 AM Mirco Ravanelli <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Sure! The content of the sentence itself is not important. What is
> important is give the network the right set of labels
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/mravanelli/SincNet/issues/3#issuecomment-423024167>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AmZiiG9ezfZh3fPoA7VGZmOqBod15k8wks5ucwSCgaJpZM4WtMcl>
> .
>

This is speaker verification task and not a speaker identification task (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaker_recognition). You can train a network as I described in the previous messages and then just apply a threshold on the output corresponding to your "key" person.

Yes, true. This is sort of a speaker verification task indeed. I can try
out the threshold way of distilling the o.p

Regards,
Sivam.

Hello -
I was able to prepare the data set for training and testing.
I am using VM box to run the speaker_id. There is no cuda capability on
this VM. Hence the error:CUDA driver version insufficient for CUDA runtime
version error appears. Is there any way I can avoid CUDA/GPU calls and run
the whole set on CPu itself?

Also, while preparing the data, there are two lines in the code to remove
the silence (crop). They seem to give some format related issue. For the
time being I have circumvented those and proceeded further. So the sole
issue seems to be with CUDA. Can you please help me there?

Regards,
Sivam.

> .
>
using a GPU for these kind of experiments is highly recommended. To work on cpu, try to remove all the ".cuda()" from the code...

True. Using gpu definitely helps. But my machine does not have one. Will
try removing .cuda() and try out. There are few calls like cnn.cuda(). If I
remove this line how will I get cnn executed?

Regards,
Sivam.

Regards, Sivam.

@mravanelli/SincNet <SincNet@noreply.github.com>
I am trying now with the GPU. I am getting an internal to Cuda error as
follows:

--
/opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1532506944876/work/aten/src/THCUNN/ClassNLLCriterion.cu:105:
void cunn_ClassNLLCriterion_updateOutput_kernel(Dtype *, Dtype *, Dtype *,
long *, Dtype *, int, int, int, int, long) [with Dtype = float, Acctype =
float]: block: [0,0,0], thread: [3,0,0] Assertion `t >= 0 && t < n_classes`
failed.
/opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1532506944876/work/aten/src/THCUNN/ClassNLLCriterion.cu:105:
void cunn_ClassNLLCriterion_updateOutput_kernel(Dtype *, Dtype *, Dtype *,
long *, Dtype *, int, int, int, int, long) [with Dtype = float, Acctype =
float]: block: [0,0,0], thread: [18,0,0] Assertion `t >= 0 && t <
n_classes` failed.
/opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1532506944876/work/aten/src/THCUNN/ClassNLLCriterion.cu:105:
void cunn_ClassNLLCriterion_updateOutput_kernel(Dtype *, Dtype *, Dtype *,
long *, Dtype *, int, int, int, int, long) [with Dtype = float, Acctype =
float]: block: [0,0,0], thread: [25,0,0] Assertion `t >= 0 && t <
n_classes` failed.
/opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1532506944876/work/aten/src/THCUNN/ClassNLLCriterion.cu:105:
void cunn_ClassNLLCriterion_updateOutput_kernel(Dtype *, Dtype *, Dtype *,
long *, Dtype *, int, int, int, int, long) [with Dtype = float, Acctype =
float]: block: [0,0,0], thread: [31,0,0] Assertion `t >= 0 && t <
n_classes` failed.
THCudaCheck FAIL
file=/opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1532506944876/work/aten/src/THC/generated/../THCReduceAll.cuh
line=317 error=59 : device-side assert triggered
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "speaker_id.py", line 245, in <module>
*    err = torch.mean((pred!=lab.long()).float())*
RuntimeError: cuda runtime error (59) : device-side assert triggered at
/opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1532506944876/work/aten/src/THC/generated/../THCReduceAll.cuh:317
---

Looks like something at the line highlighted does not go forward. I am
using Cuda 9.2. Let me know if you had seen this issue earlier and the
possible remedy as well.

Thanks,
Sivam.

On further debugging, I am funding the issue to be the usage of .long(). Is
there a work around to avoid this? Or some  setting to allow this .long()
to pass?

Thanks!

Mr [sivagururaman,](https://github.com/sivagururaman)
You should review code of speaker_id it will help you.
at the first you should load your model:
    `checkpoint_load = torch.load(pt_file) #pt_file is the path to the model file(*.pkl)`
and then according to checkpoint_load initialize each layer of the network:
  ```
 CNN_net.load_state_dict(checkpoint_load['CNN_model_par'])
   DNN1_net.load_state_dict(checkpoint_load['DNN1_model_par'])
   DNN2_net.load_state_dict(checkpoint_load['DNN2_model_par'])
```
Sets the network in evaluation mode:
  ```
 CNN_net.eval()
   DNN1_net.eval()
   DNN2_net.eval()
```
finally you can calculate ouput:
  ` pout=DNN2_net(DNN1_net(CNN_net(inp)))`

Missed updating. I could run these already and was also able to infer the
new samples using a trained network.

Thanks for your help anyways.
